column2: Still continuing his fleet career, the Headless Horseman galloped on over the prairie--Zeb Stump following only with his eyes; and not until he had passed out of sight, behind some straggling groves of mezquite, did the backwoodsman abandon his kneeling position.

column2: Then only for a second or two did he stand erect--taking council with himself as to what course he should pursue.

column2: The episode--strange as unexpected--had caused some disarrangement in his ideas, and seemed to call for a change in his plans.

column2: He might capture the Headless Horseman, and ascertain from _him_ the why and wherefore of his wild wanderings?

column2: What Zeb now saw was a man on horseback--a real horseman, with a head upon his shoulders.

column2: He was still a long way off; and it was not likely he had seen the tall form of the hunter, standing shored up among the bushes--much less the mare, lying beneath them.

column2: Zeb had not long to wait for the gratification of his wish.

column2: Ef ye make ere a stir--even to the shakin' o' them long lugs o' yourn--I'll cut yur darned throat."

column2: The last speech was an apostrophe to the "maar"--after which Zeb waxed silent, with his head among the spray of the acacias, and his eyes peering through the branches in acute scrutiny of him who was coming along.
column3: The last speech was an apostrophe to the "maar"--after which Zeb waxed silent, with his head among the spray of the acacias, and his eyes peering through the branches in acute scrutiny of him who was coming along.

column2: This was a man, who, once seen, was not likely to be soon forgotten. Scarce thirty years old, he showed a countenance, scathed, less with care than the play of evil passions.
column3: This was a man, who, once seen, was not likely to be soon forgotten. Scarce thirty years old, he showed a countenance, scathed, less with care than the play of evil passions.

column2: But there was care upon it now--a care that seemed to speak of apprehension--keen, prolonged, yet looking forward with a hope of being relieved from it.

column2: Withal it was a handsome face: such as a gentleman need not have been ashamed of, but for that sinister expression that told of its belonging to a blackguard.

column2: The dress--but why need we describe it?

column2: The blue cloth frock of semi-military cut--the forage cap--the belt sustaining a bowie-knife, with a brace of revolving pistols--all have been mentioned before as enveloping and equipping the person of Captain Cassius Calhoun.

column2: It was he.

column2: With but short time spent in consideration, so Zeb concluded; and commenced making preparations for a stalk after Cassius Calhoun.

column2: These consisted in taking hold of the bridle, and giving the old mare a kick; that caused her to start instantaneously to her feet.
